title: Transit
descriptions:
Transit (2012) is a taut crime-thriller about a family road trip gone very wrong, blending a heist-gone-bad with a desperate survival story. The plot centers on Nate, a recently paroled father trying to rebuild trust with his wife and two sons. Hoping to reconnect, he organizes a quiet camping trip, insisting on proving he’s changed despite a history that keeps him under suspicion with both the law and his family. His wife, Robin, is strained but willing to try; their teenage son is resentful and skeptical; their younger boy is anxious and easily rattled. The family’s simmering tensions set the stage for a volatile journey.

Parallel to their departure, a crew of hardened criminals—led by the ruthless Marek and his volatile partners—pulls off a high-stakes armored-car robbery. They make off with a fortune in cash but quickly realize the heavy law enforcement response will make any conventional getaway nearly impossible. Racing to avoid roadblocks, they stash the money in a seemingly random vehicle to evade detection, choosing Nate’s family car at a roadside stop. Their plan is to shadow the family, recover the loot when the heat dies down, and disappear. But the unwitting civilians do not stick to a predictable script.

Back on the highway, Nate’s family is pulled over at a police checkpoint. The presence of hidden cash—unknown to them—opens the door to suspicion. Nate, with his criminal record, immediately feels the pressure. Officers treat him as the likely problem, and the family’s frustration grows as the past can’t be shaken off. Yet a quick search does not uncover the money; the criminals have hidden it cleverly. The family is allowed to continue, but the encounter heightens everyone’s anxiety and compounds the fracture lines running through the household. Nate is determined to keep the trip on track, while his wife doubts his judgment and the boys increasingly resent what feels like another of their dad’s misguided undertakings.

Marek and his crew follow at a distance, shifting from patient tail to aggressive pursuit as circumstances change. One member of the gang is unpredictable and violent, itching to force a confrontation that Marek, calculating and cold, would prefer to avoid. Time is not on their side: police checkpoints tighten, descriptions circulate, and their getaway window narrows. The criminals’ belief that a family will be easy to manipulate proves mistaken once they see Nate’s stubborn streak and the chaotic dynamics that make the family’s movements hard to predict.

When the criminals first attempt to retrieve the money, they approach with deception, pretending to be helpful strangers or lawmen. This quickly devolves into intimidation, and the family’s confusion turns to terror as masked figures threaten them and demand the trunk. Nate, realizing something is horribly wrong and that his family has been dragged into a violent crime without their knowledge, tries to defuse the situation while keeping his loved ones safe. A botched exchange escalates into a chase off the main road and into rural back routes, where the gang believes they can operate without quick police interference.

The film escalates into a cat-and-mouse game along desolate highways, backwoods cut-throughs, and remote stopovers. Nate is forced to draw on instincts he would rather deny—resourcefulness that once got him into trouble, now repurposed to protect his family. The criminals, meanwhile, splinter under pressure. Greed clashes with paranoia; loyalties fray. A hot-headed member acts independently, jeopardizing Marek’s carefully laid plans. Their internal power struggle gives Nate small but crucial openings to exploit.

Robin gradually shifts from skeptic to ally, recognizing that Nate’s determination is not bravado but a genuine drive to shield them. She becomes an active participant in their survival, helping improvise distractions and stand-offs. Their boys, particularly the teenager, move from sullen detachment to engagement, learning hard truths about their father’s past while seeing his present choices—the courage and sacrifice he’s willing to make. The family’s survival depends on unity, which they slowly reclaim under pressure.

Key set pieces include a tense sequence at a lonely roadside store where the criminals corner the family, forcing them to act quickly and cleverly to escape without a casualty. Another involves a nighttime standoff near a swampy detour, where Nate uses the terrain and darkness to turn the tables on one pursuer. Throughout, the money—bundled and hidden—is more curse than prize, a magnet for violence that brings out the worst in the criminals and forces the best from the embattled family.

Calling the police could backfire into immediate handcuffs for him, and he knows that one wrong move will confirm the worst suspicions about his character.
